title: Over-sea;
author: Morford, Henry
snippet: Temple so sacred to the legal profession for many a lon^ year, with the offices or clianibers of the lawyers surrounding,  and showing their old dingy entrances on three sides, and the fourth — that farthest from the street — occupied by the Old Temple Church, pez'haps one of the most interesting  of all the things of old time around the great metropolis. That small but elegant Gothic cathedral building dates back to Edward the First, in 1270 ; and that round, J^orman domed pile, the Chapter-house, was built in 1185, and formed the head-quarters or religious home of the Knight Templars in Great Britain, (a body whom the Masons in America have good cause to remember I) when they poured forth their valiant numbers to the crusades, under Henry the Second and John and Richard Cour-de-Lion.

title: Rambles in America, past and present.
author: Pairpoint, Alfred J.
snippet: A calm, subdued tone always seemed to rest in this sacred place, just aside from the busy hum of Fleet Street. The pillars supporting the interior roof of the stately Temple Church were found out by accident a few years since to be encrusted with a sort of cement, which being carefully removed, discovered polished  marble, and the pillars have been since thoroughly restored.

title: Over-Sea; or, England, France and Scotland as seen by a live American ... With numerous illustrations, etc
author: Morford, Henry.
snippet: Temple so sacred to the legal profession for many a longyear, with the offices or chambers of the lawyers surrounding, and showing their old dingy entrances on three sides,and the fourth—that farthest from the street—occupied bythe Old Temple Church, perhaps one of the most interesting of all the things of old time around the great metropolis. That small but elegant Gothic cathedral building dates backto Edward the First, in 1270 ; and that round, Normandomed pile, the Chapter-house, was built in 1185, andformed the head-quarters or religious home of the KnightTemplars in Great Britain, (a body whom the Masons inAmerica have good cause to remember !) when they pouredforth their valiant numbers to the crusades, under Henry theSecond and John and Richard Cour-de-Lion.

title: Passages from the English Notebooks, Volume 2.
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
snippet: We next went to the Temple Church, and, finding the door ajar, made freeto enter beneath its Norman arches, which admitted us into a circularvestibule, very ancient and beautiful. In the body of the church beyondwe saw a boy sitting, but nobody either forbade or invited our entrance.

title: Passages from the English Notebooks, Complete
author: Hawthorne, Nathaniel
snippet: We next went to the Temple Church, and, finding the door ajar, made freeto enter beneath its Norman arches, which admitted us into a circularvestibule, very ancient and beautiful. In the body of the church beyondwe saw a boy sitting, but nobody either forbade or invited our entrance.

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: The Temple Church is also an object of interest to all Knights Templars, as it dates back to 1188. It is divided into sections, known as the Eound Church and the Choir which was added in 1240.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: At this point, I can not refrain from making anothercopious quotation from the elegant address of Sir andBro. S. W. Young, to whom I am already so muchbeholden for the valuable materials which I have in-corporated, with others, in the sketch of " Yorkand its relations to Freemasonry," in the secondchapter of this work, and I feel sure that I will bereadily pardoned by my readers when they peruse SirYoung's truly eloquent and learned remarks, in con-nection with the Temple Church, which we have beenfeebly attempting to describe, though never so imperfectly, I am afraid.

title: A Knight Templar abroad; or, Reminiscences of travel beyond the sea
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: The Temple Church is also an object of interest toall Knights Templars, as it dates back to 1188. It isdivided into sections, known as the Round Church andthe Choir which was added in 1240.

title: Rambles in America, past and present.
author: Pairpoint, Alfred J.
snippet: The windings of Old London are here perceived, running down to the banks of the Thames embankment, and the venerable buildings  in the quadrangles, courts, and alleys are chiefly occupied  by lawyers, barristers, and benchers of the Temple. The writer of this book, years ago, on Sabbath days often visited Temple Church, listening to good sermons and excellent  singing of the well-trained choristers. A calm, subdued tone always seemed to rest in this sacred place, just aside from the busy hum of Fleet Street.

title: Rambles in America, past and present.
author: Pairpoint, Alfred J.
snippet: Boswell and many others used to meet at their club gatherings  at the old-fashioned coffee-houses .and taverns, for discussion  and hilarity. We pass on to what used to be called Temple Gardens, in the midst of which stands a line, ancient, sacred edifice, named " The Temple Church." The windings of Old London are here perceived, running down to the banks of the Thames embankment, and the venerable buildings  in the quadrangles, courts, and alleys are chiefly occupied  by lawyers, barristers, and benchers of the Temple.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: Many seek it, but none find ! The honorary tomb in Westminster  Abbey is a mockery, when one is made acquainted with these facts. Some admirers of the bard have placed a beautiful marble tribute to his memory, in the vestry of Temple Church, on which is engraved the following : —

title: A knight templar abroad;
author: Cord, W. Harlan.
snippet: At this point, I can not refrain from making another copious quotation from the elegant address of Sir and Bro. S. W. Young, to whom I am already so much beholden for the valuable materials which I have incorporated,  with others, in the sketch of " York and its relations to Freemasonry," in the second chapter of this work, and I feel sure that I will be readily pardoned by my readers when they peruse Sir Young's truly eloquent and learned remarks, in connection  with the Temple Church, which we have been feebly attempting to describe, though never so imperfectly,  I am afraid.
